Hi Joe,

I)
^((\w\w\w,\w*)|((au|uk),\w*,\w*)|[\w,]{8})
This one has been used with 6 machine crawls with focus on the 
Australian domain.

II)
^((((au|uk),gov|fr,gouv|ca,gc|(int|org),un),\w*)|(\w\w\w,\w*)|[\w,]{0,7}\w*)
This one has been used with 6 machine crawls with focus on government 
sites from US, UK, CA, AU, FR and UN.

III)
^(((\w\w\w,|fr,(asso|com|gouv|nom|prd|presse|tm|aero|cci),|fr,)\w*)|[\w,]{4})
This one has been used with 4 machine crawls with focus on the French 
domain. Notice that French domain has a few specific second top level 
domains.

I think that these three patterns will give you a general idea on what 
has to be done for a World Wide broad crawl.


As you are probably already aware, you will need to watch out for 
domains with a large number of subdomains.

For example:
1) skyblog.com/skyrock.com will have about 2+ million subdomains; one 
for each user/blog. These subdomains are virtual hosts that are hosted 
from some number of machines. If you don't have a reduce pattern to 
force them all to a single machine you might hit them very hard (many 
connections from each crawler node). On the other hand, if you put them 
all on a single machine, 2+ million hosts will eventually starve 
anything else on that machine.
I personally like to put them to a single machine and use 
force-queue-assignment in per host overrides to simulate IP politeness. 
You might not get as much content as you want but that can be increased 
via budgeting (see queue-total-budget and balance-replenish-amount options).

2) nasa.gov has about 3000+ subdomains, but notice that we do not have 
specific rule for it in the second reduce pattern from above. Majority 
of these NASA subdomains are not virtual hosts and they can handle a 
load -- our tax money at work :)

Obviously there is no single solution that fits them all, but with 
reduce pattern, per host overrides, IP like politeness and budgeting you 
should be able to create a good generic configuration.

Take care,
i.
